title: It’s war. Snowball war.
text:
Keith Bedford/Globe staff
A man reacted to being hit during a snowball fight on Boston Common Thursday.
By Steve Annear Globe Staff February 09, 2017
At noon, it’s war.
Around 1,000 people have said on Facebook that they plan to attend a giant snowball fight on Boston Common Thursday, as a nor’easter that’s expected to drop up to 15 inches of snow in some areas barrels down on the state.
Advertisement
Organizers have invited people interested in pummeling one another with handfuls of the stuff to meet at the Parkman Bandstand, which is a short walk from Tremont Street.
“Invite anyone and everyone,” said a post on an event page for the gathering.

Sign up for more newsletters here The heaviest snowfall is expected to last until 5 p.m. Motorists have been asked to stay off the roads, and schools and colleges in the area have closed for the day.
View Gallery Photos: Snowstorm means snowball fight
Scott Schaffer, an Emerson College student who is organizing the event, said he’s expecting a decent turnout.
“It seems like a whole lot of people are interested,” he said in a message to the Globe. “I’m hoping for something big.”
Advertisement
He said the idea to host the event on the Common was spur of the moment.
“I knew all the colleges in the city would have their classes canceled so I just thought it would be a great idea,” he said. “I invited all my friends from the different schools and it just blew up. Totally unexpected, but in a great way.”
Massive snowball fights have become something of a tradition during serious snowstorms in the region.
In 2013, around 50 people showed up for a planned snowball fight on the Common, following winter storm “Nemo.”
And last year, the “colleges of Boston” tried to bring together students to battle it out at the public park.
